awd_titl_txt: Multi-modal Mass Spectrometric Imaging for Understanding the Biochemical Effects of Nanomaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Richard Vachet, Professor Vincent Rotello, and their groups at the University of Massachusetts-Amherst are developing new methods to measure nanomaterials in biological samples. Nanomaterials are important in a growing number of technologies, ranging from consumer goods and industrial applications to biomedicine. To properly understand the consequences of such nanomaterials in each application, new measurement methods are needed that can report on their distributions and biochemical effects. Professors Vachet and Rotello are developing new imaging tools that can simultaneously provide both sets of information for nanomaterials in tissues. The proposed imaging methods rely on sophisticated laser-based mass spectrometry that can also provide fundamental information about the interactions of light with nanomaterials. The new methods developed in this grant are also leading to new ways to computationally combine data obtained from these new imaging methods and more traditional microscopy methods, thereby deepening the insight that can be extracted from these imaging methods. A diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students will be involved in the project, and these students will obtain training in cutting-edge mass spectrometry and nanotechnology, two areas of broad importance.

The Vachet/Rotello group is developing new imaging approaches that combine laser ablation inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP MS) and matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization MS (MALDI MS) to simultaneously track nanomaterials and biomolecules (e.g. metabolites, lipids) in tissues. They are exploring new multi-modal image segmentation approaches to more easily identify sub-organ specific molecular markers. They are also developing new computational methods to fuse images from LA-ICP-MS imaging, MALDI-MS imaging, and microscopy. Combining images from these modalities will improve spatial resolution and enhance the chemical information present in the images. They are also synthesizing new mass tags that can be conjugated to any nanomaterial to improve multi-modal imaging. New software that is developed in this project is made freely available to the research community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: During this project, we successfully combined laser ablation inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) imaging, matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry imaging, and optical microscopy to enhance the detection and localization of nanomaterials in tissues. When combined in the appropriate manner, these imaging methods work synergistically to provide deeper insight into how nanomaterials affect tissue biology. Using LA-ICP-MS, we have also created a straightforward new method for quantitatively imaging polymeric nanomaterials, which are inherently difficult to detect in biological samples. In addition, we have proof-of-principle data that shows we can computationally fuse LA-ICP-MS and microscopy images to create higher resolution LA-ICP-MS images, paving the way to image the biodistributions of elements with close to cellular resolution without additional experimental time or equipment. Upon applying our new multimodal imaging approaches, we have obtained mechanistic information about how new cancer-targeting nanozymes and antimicrobial nanomaterials work to reduce tumor size and destroy biofilms, respectively.

 

Broader Impacts: Nanomaterials are attractive for therapeutic and industrial applications. They are also increasingly used in consumer products. Our new imaging methods afford unprecedented insight into nanomaterial distributions and their biological effects in organisms. The information that is provided by these new methods will improve the design of nanomaterials to maximize their desired functions while minimizing any negative biological consequences. Already, these methods have yielded important insight into how novel cancer-targeting nanozymes and antimicrobial nanomaterials work. As our methods are adopted and used by other researchers, we expect them to have an impact in industrial, diagnostic, and medical applications. Our research has also positively influenced the training of a new batch of scientists, including six PhD and six BS students. Each was trained in the areas of nanotechnology and mass spectrometry, which are research areas that are having a broad impact in many fields of science and technology. Moreover, 50% of the students who received training as part of this project are women, who are underrepresented in the chemical sciences.


Last Modified: 08/21/2024
Modified by: Richard W Vachet

Images (1 of )
  • (a) Ag in a treated MRSA biofilm. (b) Ag in an untreated biofilm. (c) Zn in a treated MRSA biofilm. Low Zn levels indicate fewer bacterial cells. (d) Zn in an untreated biofilm. (e) Ag and Zn signal intensities per pixel in individual biofilm samples.
    Vincent Rotello
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Richard W Vachet
    LA-ICP-MS images and data from a methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) biofilm after 1 h of incubation with Ag nanoclusters that have been incorporated into polymeric biodegradable nanoemulsions.
  • (a) LA-ICP-MS Fe image. (b) MALDI-MS heme b image. (c) MALDI-MS segmentation via k-means clustering. (d) MALDI-MS segmentation via bisecting k-means. (e) LA-ICP-MS based segmentation. MALDI-MS images overlaid with the (f) red pulp (RP), (g) marginal zone (MZ), and (h) white pulp (WP).
    Richard Vachet
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Richard W Vachet
    LA-ICP-MS assisted segmentation of MALDI-MS images.
  • (a) The polymeric nanomaterial self-assembles with a model protein, and each is conjugated to a different metal, allowing them to be separately tracked by ICP-MS. (b) Workflow for fluorescence and LA-ICP-MS imaging of polymer and protein biodistributions in tissues.
    Richard Vachet
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Richard W Vachet
    Design for making polymeric nanomaterials and their protein cargo detectable by mass spectrometry.
